results.title: SIR Modeling
results.content: Below is a plot that shows how the infection dynamics are impacted under each strategy. The left facet shows the percentage of the population that is infectious (\(I\_t/N\)) and the right facet gives the percentage of population that has been infected (\((I\_t + R\_t)/N\)). The baseline model uses \(\beta=0.30, \gamma=1/10\) (\(R\_0 = 3.0\)) in a population of 100,000 people. This implies that each infectious individual will come into contagiously close contact with an average of 0.30 people [...] per day and will stay contagious for an average of 10 days. On day 1, there is a single infectious person leaving \(S\_1=99{,}999\) susceptible, and \(R\_1=0\) recovered. Strategy 1 reduces \(\beta=0.25\), Strategy 2 increases \(\gamma=1/8\) (contagious for 8 days on average), and Strategy 3 considers that 10% of the population is immune on day 1 (\(S\_1=90{,}000\)). [...] The baseline scenario is the same as what was considered in Changing the Disease Dynamics section, \(\beta=0.30, \gamma=1/10\) (\(R\_0 = 3.0\)). The other scenarios consider that \(\beta\) is reduced to \(0.20\) on a certain day (e.g., due to a shelter in place order). The top left panel is the baseline scenario. The other panels show how the infectious rate varies if the intervention occurs at different time points in the course of the epidemic. The black line is provided as a reference to the

Using a fixed population,  in the three functions resolves that the value  should remain constant within the simulation, if a simulation is used to solve the SIR model. Alternatively, the analytic approximant can be used without performing a simulation. The model is started with values of ,  and . These are the number of people in the susceptible, infected and removed categories at time equals zero. If the SIR model is assumed to hold at all times, these initial conditions are not independent. [...] ### Steady-state solutions

[edit&action=edit&section=9 "Edit section: Steady-state solutions")]

The only steady state solution to the classic SIR model as defined by the differential equations above is I=0, S and R can then take any values. The model can be changed while retaining three compartments to give a steady-state endemic solution by adding some input to the S compartment. results.query: typical gamma values for SIR model in disease transmission simulations
results.answer: Typical recoveryâ€‘rate parameters (Î³) used in SIR simulations fall in the range of roughly 0.05 to 0.2â€¯dayâ»Â¹, corresponding to average infectious periods of about 5â€“20â€¯days; for example, many COVIDâ€‘19 studies adopt Î³â‰ˆ0.1â€¯dayâ»Â¹ (â‰ˆ10â€‘day infectious period), influenza models often use Î³â‰ˆ0.2â€¯dayâ»Â¹ (â‰ˆ5â€‘day period), and measles or other slowerâ€‘recovering infections may be represented with Î³â‰ˆ0.07â€“0.14â€¯dayâ»Â¹ (â‰ˆ7â€“14â€‘day periods).

results.title: Fractional SIR epidemiological models | Scientific Reports - Nature
results.content: Our thesis is supported by simulation results as well as by fitting this fSIR model to recent COVID-19 datasets. Specifically, the two-dimensional discrete probabilistic SIR models in Figs. 2 and 3 (with \(k=4\) nearest-neighbor connection) and in Figs. 4 and 5 (with \(k=8\) nearest-neighbor connection), that simulate disease propagation on a discrete domain of nodes (representing individuals in contact with one another), suggest exponents \(\gamma \) in the range between 0.66 and 0.76 for the [...] Regarding (2), we have numerically studied data that is available in7, 533â€“534 (2020).") on the recent COVID-19 epidemic. We focused on the dynamics of transmission in four countries (Italy, Germany, France, and Spain) during the early phases of the epidemic. For the specific datasets we considered, as we explained in the results, the exponent \(\gamma \) in (2) ranges from about 0.6 to 0.8. Coincidentally, the values appear similar to empirically determined exponents of the NSM model. [...] incidence rates, especially with exponents \(\gamma >1\) that lead to rich dynamical behavior studied in17, 187â€“204 (1986)."). The SIR model implicitly assumes that the infectious period is exponentially distributed with 1/_Î³_ being the mean value of the infectious period. Although it is an option to assume that the infectious period is exponential distribution (see Fig.1), it is also an attempt to assume that the infectious period is other distribution. In previous studies, it is found that the infectious stage of many infectious diseases may be closer to the gamma distribution(Feng et al., 2007; Wearing et al., [...] 2. Model and analysis

results.title: Revisiting classical SIR modelling in light of the COVID-19 pandemic

agent_response:
Reason: To provide a comprehensive answer about typical beta and gamma values in SIR disease transmission models, I need to synthesize information from credible sources on the ranges and example values of these parameters used in common epidemiological simulations. Beta (Î²) represents the transmission rate, and gamma (Î³) represents the recovery rate, crucial elements defining disease spread and infectious period respectively.

Action: Summarize findings from search results highlighting typical beta values, typical gamma values, and example scenarios from disease modeling literature to give a clear and concrete understanding of common parameter values and their interpretation.

Observation: 
- Typical beta (Î²) values range roughly from 0.1 to 0.5 per day, commonly around 0.3 per day in textbook examples, implying each infectious person infects 0.3 people per day on average.
- Beta varies based on disease transmissibility and contact rates; lower values like 0.02 to 0.05 per day are seen in slower-spread pathogens.
- Typical gamma (Î³) values generally range from 0.05 to 0.2 per day, corresponding to infectious periods of roughly 5 to 20 days.
- For example, Î³ â‰ˆ 0.1/day implies an average infectious period of 10 days (1/Î³), often used for COVID-19; influenza models use Î³ â‰ˆ 0.2/day (~5 days infectious period).
- Specific modeling studies use Î² = 0.3/day and Î³ = 1/10 day^-1 (0.1/day), with an implied R0 = Î²/Î³ = 3, as a baseline scenario.
- Variations account for disease, control measures, population behavior, etc.

Final Thought: The typical parameter values for SIR models in disease transmission simulations fall in these ranges, with Î² around 0.1 to 0.5 per day (often ~0.3), and Î³ around 0.05 to 0.2 per day (commonly ~0.1), reflecting typical infectious periods of 5-20 days. These parameters are crucial for defining the transmission dynamics and are selected based on the disease characteristics and context of the simulation.

Final Answer: 

In SIR (Susceptible-Infectious-Recovered) models of disease transmission, the typical ranges for the key parameters beta (Î²) and gamma (Î³) are as follows:

- **Beta (Î²)**: The transmission rate, representing the rate at which an infectious individual contacts susceptible individuals and transmits the infection, generally ranges from about 0.1 to 0.5 per day. Many teaching examples often use Î² â‰ˆ 0.3 per day, which implies that each infectious person infects, on average, 0.3 people per day. For slower-spreading infections, smaller values such as 0.02 to 0.05 per day may be used. The exact Î² depends on the contagiousness of the disease and contact frequency in the population.

- **Gamma (Î³)**: The recovery rate, indicating the rate at which infected individuals recover and move to the recovered class, typically ranges from about 0.05 to 0.2 per day. This corresponds to an average infectious period (1/Î³) of 5 to 20 days. For instance, COVID-19 models often use Î³ â‰ˆ 0.1/day, implying around 10 days of infectiousness. Influenza models might use Î³ â‰ˆ 0.2/day for a roughly 5-day infectious period, while diseases like measles could have lower Î³ values corresponding to longer infectious durations.

For example, a common baseline SIR model might use Î² = 0.3/day and Î³ = 0.1/day, resulting in a basic reproduction number R0 = Î²/Î³ = 3, indicating that an infected person infects three others on average in a fully susceptible population.

These parameters are chosen based on the biological understanding of the disease's contagiousness and recovery time, as well as assumptions about population behavior and contact patterns. Adjustments to Î² and Î³ allow models to simulate interventions such as social distancing (lower Î²) or improved treatment reducing infectious duration (higher Î³).
